The director-writer team have crafted a great-looking and sincere genre throwback without resorting to pastiche of some of their peers.
At almost two hours, the film feels every minute of it, building to a climax that basically amounts to the platitude "being a father is really hard."
Not as arty as The American or Tinker Tailor Soldier Spy or as soapy and quickly paced as its small screen counterparts, A Most Wanted Man is left somewhere in the middle.
Despite some good performances and sharp screenplay, C.O.G., like its lead character, seems stuck in the space between.
It's a very small-scale, unassuming relationship movie (with a heady little twist), but it sneaks up on you.
You may not realize until you're watching The To Do List how refreshing it is just to see this familiar story told from the female perspective.

The desire to escape your hometown and reshape your identity is potentially rich territory to explore but the script by Michelle Morgan looks only to mine from the surface so you end up with trite lessons about how there's no place like home.
Submarine is a remarkably assured debut filled with dry humor, inventive visual wit and great performances.
...An enjoyable coming-of-age film but a few of the darker sequences and the general feeling that you've seen this story before might keep it from being a larger success.
Despite some tonal stumbles, the film mostly finds its footing and becomes an enjoyable comic enterprise.
The momentum from the opening dissipates early and without a real engine pushing the movie foward, it begins to drag...the film is 87 minutes and feels like it's 2 hours.
A bizarre, well intentioned mess, at the very least, Detachment is never dull...even as the film is bad, it's compulsively watchable.
It seems, ironically, much more amateurish than any of Roth's previous features, to the point where you start to wonder why he chose this as his comeback vehicle.
Shaun the Sheep is a deceptively simple character, and Shaun the Sheep Movie is a deceptively simple film.
As a cracking tale of code-cracking, Angels & Demons never really works. Howard doesn't create the drama of a great mind facing great challenges, struggling to see the truth as the clock ticks.
Johnson's film is meant to be a heartwarming and funny look at young dreamers and the realities of their lives. But there's something distasteful in portraying these kids as lovable losers.
The film combines stunning visuals - there are scenes of incredible beauty - with good old-fashioned storytelling that is funny, inventive and at times scary. Destined to be a classic.
Here is a film that slaps your expectations around with surprise after surprise, leaving you shaking your head in disbelief that a Star Trek film could be this good.
X-Men Origins is really a series of action sequences, the usual mix of bangs, chases and fights, held together by a plot so predictable that you get no points for guessing right.

Does this film warrant one star for being so ugly, violent, misogynistic, sexist and racist - or five stars for being a daring and disturbing study of the violence, ugliness, sexism and racism of the ordinary American male?
The film slips into American schmaltz at times, but it's really a thing of wonder - an infectious and irresistible fantasy that all the family can enjoy.
State of Play is enjoyable, but this is not a great thriller. It's a cold film that has no emotional drive, no defining mood of tension or paranoia.
Written and directed by a newcomer, Eric Guirado, this is a delightful coming-of-age film that quietly explores the hidden tensions in family life.
movie_title: Le fils de l'épicier (The Grocer's Son) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: This is a classic Kaufmanesque work: bold, bizarre and utterly baffling.

Given its harrowing theme, Helen is a beautiful and restrained work. The camera quietly and slowly glides along Helen's world, laying bare the loneliness of a marginalised girl who is longing to find a life of her own.
Though the performances are all first-rate, the film is let down by weak characterisation. Still, it's enjoyable, if not exceptional.
movie_title: La Fille Coupée en Deux (The Girl Cut in Two) (A Girl Cut in Two) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: It has a good cast and a terrific 1980s soundtrack (Devo, Simple Minds), but it also has the superficiality of a TV soap. The Informers is not so bad that you can't sit back and enjoy it, but nor is it good enough to go and see.

Levy's film is neither fun nor exciting. He's stuffed it with special effects, star names and big numbers, but it has none of the exuberance needed to lift us out of our seats and take us on a thrilling ride.
movie_title: Night at the Museum 2: Battle of the Smithsonian (2009)

movie_review_blurb: The high tension that should come with a race-against-time scenario is never realised, and the film's solution to the enigma of who-what-and-why this all happened is disappointing.
The film has great visual flair, but the story is a heavy-handed slice of modern melodrama that would have made Dickens blush.
Loach has created the first real grim-meets-feelgood film. It offers guilt-free fun and laughs for football and Loach fans alike.
Lacks dramatic punch and satirical bite - it's all rather cartoonish - but it's full of great characters and moves at an energetic pace. This is a superior buddy film.
Instead of something fresh and funny, this film is as formulaic and empty as any Hollywood blockbuster.
Too silly to be smart, too timid to be subversive about religion - it's hard to believe it's directed and co-written by the once great Harold Ramis
The dialogue is a nice mix of Pinteresque menace, drug lingo, laddism and cracking one-liners.
This is a Potter film that will be quickly forgotten, even by Harry's most ardent fans.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Moon is a gripping sci-fi tale, but also has a lot of heart and humanity.
Skin is one of those worthy and watchable dramas that are un-demanding and a bit underwhelming. It should leave you with a big lump in your throat, but it's strangely unemotional.
The film avoids sentimentality, yet there's no denying that we sighted people end up feeling sorry for them - something I don't think they would want.
In the Loop is a fast and furious farce that looks and feels authentic.
Brilliant performances from Streep and Hoffman, however, make it well worth seeing.
Strictly for wave fans.
Yes, it's good... But how good?
movie_title: The Lord of the Rings: The Two Towers (2002)

movie_review_blurb: It's neither an exciting thriller nor an interesting study in character. And there is no memorable iconic moment featuring Bond, his baddies or his beauties, the kind that you take home from the cinema and that stays with you.
Like a variation on Death in Venice, only this could be Death in Kentish Town.
The best thing about it is the convincing acting by DiCaprio and Hounsou.
If Estevez's drama had been as strong as [RFK's] speech, Bobby would have been a far better film.
There are harrowing moments: who could not be moved by a parent talking about a son's suicide? But you do not leave the cinema with a better understanding of suicide.
The film is silly when it should be sexy, witless when trying to be funny. Everyone involved is probably deeply embarrassed to be associated with it.
The whole dream-like effect the film strives for is undermined by the poor acting.
With Hellboy II, the comic-book blockbuster has finally grown up - without giving up the fairy-tale wonders of our youth.

As a film, it's a touch too Hollywood, and full of too much patriotic Braveheart guff, but, on the whole, the American director and writer, Charles Martin Smith, has created an amiable and watchable heist movie.

Frost/Nixon is a historical fraud, a mind-boggling travesty of the truth. Let me hasten to add, however, that it is without doubt the most gripping, entertaining, dramatically clever and fascinating fraud I've ever seen.
The film is a fresh and memorable mix of grimy realism and gothic fantasy.
Milk is a powerful film that leaves a lump in your throat. It has a magnificent performance from Sean Penn.
Nick & Norah is a teen comedy that adults can enjoy. The screenplay, by Lorene Scafaria, manages to be smart and sophisticated, the comedy dry and understated.
If ever there were a film that aimed for the zeitgeist and missed badly, it's this one.
For all its meditations on romantic disappointments, this is a slight, sunny film. Anyone in need of some superior escapism should see it straightaway.
The Curious Case of Benjamin Button is an anodyne Hollywood film that offers a safe and sanitised view of life and death. It's Forrest Gump goes backwards.
movie_title: The Curious Case of Benjamin Button (2008)

movie_review_blurb: The sight of Bullock doing a rap dance with granny in the woods is a traumatising experience.
The music is good, the suits are sharp, but it's the outstanding performances that wow. Walker is electrifying as Howlin' Wolf and Beyoncé - playing Etta James - has never been so sultry and sexy.
Seeing the new inclusive Clint shows an old dog can learn new tricks. But like Walt himself, I can't help but prefer Dirty Harry to Caring Clint any day.
The International is being presented as a "thriller for our times", but it's too far-fetched to be relevant. Still, it's an enjoyable yarn.
The film raises important questions about learning, authority and discipline, and is honest enough to admit that it doesn't really have any answers.
Curtis has failed to give us characters we can really like.
Maher has gone for easy targets. He comes up with the odd funny gag, but you get the feeling that he is as dogmatic about his doubt as the believers are about their faith.
Valkyrie isn't a great war movie, but within its own limited ambitions, it is enjoyable and never dull.
Von Trier has mutilated his own film, turning it into a crazy, hysterical work that alienates the audience with its infantile shock tactics and tedious transgressions.
All sound and fury, devoid of any relevance or resonance.
It's a work of hagiography that serves neither history nor its subject well.
The film isn't funny enough or serious enough to be of substance, and often sinks into the quagmire of its own quirkiness.
A charming spoof of cold-war alien paranoia, this is visually inventive and full of action, but could do with more humour.
The acting is stiff, the special effects look cheap and the dialogue is unintentionally funny.
For theatre buffs who know about that era, this is a treat.

Like a sitcom pilot that should never have seen the light of day. The characters are cardboard cutouts and the comedy lacks bite. Imagine the same script featuring white characters and you will see just how second-rate the screenplay is.
The trouble with his new film, though, is not its lack of grit, but its lack of ambition and originality. It's one of those films that you've seen before - even before you've seen it.
movie_title: Did You Hear About the Morgans? (2009)

movie_review_blurb: It's a good-looking film that is fun and comic, with fine performances from Law, Downey and, especially, Strong.

Taylor-Wood has opted for a natural realism, free of arty flourishes - a style as sensible and conservative as Aunt Mimi. She is happy to provide a canvas on which her talented cast can shine, and they do.
It has the sleek, superficial stylishness of a fashion magazine shoot set in La Dolce Vita Italy. Instead of dazzle, we get the dull drizzle of Guido falling apart.
When all the hype and hullabaloo about Avatar calms down, we will be left with a film that's no masterpiece, but still well worth seeing.
For guitar freaks and fans of these guys, the film gives you a unique chance to hang out with some real guitar heroes.
Paranormal Activity is a remarkable achievement, but ultimately it's just not scary enough to be considered a horror classic.
This film is a British celebration of outsiderdom - be it the creative or the crippled - that is never sentimental.
This is a small British mockumentary with some good laughs and two likeable leads in Mangan and Thomas, but you can't escape the feeling that it is best seen at home on DVD, with a nice takeaway.
The private tragedy of George is never transformed into the gripping stuff of public drama; his story doesn't become our story. While A Single Man may dazzle the eye, it leaves the heart untouched.
If only The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo provided the food for thought the novel gave us, it would be a far better film.
movie_title: The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Despite the violence and the swearing, Kick-Ass has something you don't usually see in superhero films: charm.
The Disappearance of Alice Creed is a timely reminder that you can make a terrific film with only three characters, a two-bedroom flat (well, mostly) and a bit of imagination.
There's an outdated feel to it all, from its cold-war view of America to the AC/DC soundtrack.
Barnaby Southcombe makes a distinguished directorial debut with this stylish and atmospheric film noir.
Don't get me wrong. I'm not sulking. I liked Shrek 2. Honest. Kids will like Shrek 2. Most mums and dads will like Shrek 2. My problem is this: I didn't love it the way I loved Shrek.
I think this is the best Potter film yet, for one simple reason: it's not like a Harry Potter film.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Instead of inviting us sophisticated moderns to look back and laugh, it insists that we look back and rediscover something we have lost.

You know you have just witnessed a good musical when you leave the theatre or cinema with one, or more, of its songs still ringing in your head.... But after seeing Chicago, I did not whistle or tap my way home.
It's one of that rare breed of remarkable films - like Mel Gibson's Apocalypto - that, once you've seen it, you would be quite happy never to see again. Then again, it's so good you won't need to.
The human comedy as portrayed in this film was never so cruel - or so funny.
It's a film without much resonance - there is no way of knowing what lasting effects the pupils' experiences will have on them - but it's smoothly made by Jordan Scott.
Too shallow for satire and not funny enough for comedy, the infantile Goats is really just a silly absurdist movie trying to pass for an antiwar film.
movie_title: The Men Who Stare at Goats (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Silly sci-fi tosh that tries to play itself out as a serious and heart-rending love story, but Ghost it ain't.
Bandslam is a mix of the icky, the corny and the comic, but there's no denying that it's fun.
Despite the fresh setting and fine performances, Yildirim's screenplay is just too familiar to really admire. Instead of violent and ruthless Italians, we get violent and ruthless Turks.
This spaghetti-western-inspired war film is a watchable mix of the good, the bad and the ugly.
Bright Star is an admirable film made by a superb craftsman, but for me, Campion fails to deliver the big emotional punch she hopes to land.
The first part of the film is terrific and very funny. Apatow perfectly captures the ruthless competitiveness of young comics.

It is ironic that, of all Almodovar's films, Broken Embraces is the biggest budget and the greatest length, yet it is also the dullest. His devoted fans will be delighted, but those who enjoyed Volver will be disappointed.
The Hurt Locker is an exciting and visceral work.

Too timid to be truly cynical about love and too eager for box-office success to try to be a really new kind of romantic comedy, the film fails the ultimate romantic-comedy test: not only does it lack enough laughs, but you're never emotionally involved.
The film's tone moves easily from the comic to the cruel, and the alien creatures look authentic. From the start, the film promises a fresh and thoughtful slice of Swiftian sci-fi.
The script is appalling, the dialogue is flat, the acting is unforgivable and the horror scenes are unintentionally comic. Yes - in Carey Jones, Britain has produced its own Ed Wood.
This comedy is so bad it will make you want to tear out your eyeballs and use them as ear plugs.
It doesn't enhance the experience, because the film's timeless appeal is down to great characters and wonderful storytelling; a classic that doesn't need goggles or gimmicks.
The Invention of Lying is an underdeveloped work from an overindulged comic.
A hugely enjoyable work, whose care, craftsmanship and creative courage are rarely found in mainstream films - animated or otherwise.
Think Spinal Rap. A likeable and sporadically funny film, it's rather slight for a theatrical release.
After the mandatory splatter scenes, Ruben Fleischer's film becomes more character-driven and enjoyable.

Couples is so formulaic, so fake and relentlessly bland, it's hard to care if any of these pairings get a divorce, drown or are eaten by sharks. It has neither the ring of truth nor the fun of fantasy.

he quiet, understated setup of the first part of the film is an honest and thoughtful exploration of male ego and infertility. Then Glasson turns up the horror heat and his film becomes another bunny-boiler look at obsession.
t offers yet another celebration of difference and a lesson on the importance of being yourself. But it does leave you thinking: isn't it time that children's films put children first?
What end does a harrowing and horrifying film like this serve? Understanding? Political awareness? I'm not sure. One thing is certain: you won't forget it in a hurry.
An Education offers plenty to enjoy and admire. It's full of first-rate performances.
Atkins deserves credit for a lively and thought-provoking documentary on a subject more suitable to a book than a film.
Vinyan is a fine example of art-house horror. It's rich in spooky atmospherics, but it's not really scary.
Endearing but too safe.
This documentary will inspire you to invest in an decent camera.
movie_title: Water and Sugar: Carlo Di Palma, the Colours of Life (2016)

movie_review_blurb: A great premise poorly executed.
A layered film that demands discussion and analysis from its viewers.

Those with an appreciation for photography will find the film particularly enjoyable, as it's easy to see that the director incorporated her background in photography to manifest a visually delightful film as well as an engaging story.
Aesthetically nice with some really great practical effects, it shows that Kostanski and Gillespie have the talent and potential for a truly exciting future.
Aimy in a Cage is an annoying frenzy of a film that will push your patience further than any film should.
he Propaganda Game is an interesting documentary for those who don't have a lot of knowledge of the country but it lacks the depth and revelations that would make it a must watch on the subject.
Goodnight Mommy has a surreal, almost fairy tale quality.

It often looks great but an enjoyable first half gives way to a dull and dragging second half, due to the film's lack of focus and drive. There are things to admire and enjoy but High-Rise can't help but be a bit of a disappointment.
Though it doesn't bring anything new to the table and isn't all entirely successful, I Am Alone is an enjoyable if forgettable entry into the zombie and found footage subgenres.
It's difficult to know where to start with this film and as advice to a potential viewer, we would say it's best not to start it at all.
The Neon Demon is wonderful looking, has a great soundtrack and has some interesting ideas floating around but it tries your patience with its sluggish pace and lack of drive.

The great cast get to have a lot of fun with some enjoyable dialogue but things slow down once the shooting starts. It's just entertaining enough to last the ninety minutes but you'd rather the characters were talking rather than shooting.
With strong performances and some solid direction, Bad Frank is enjoyable and compelling through its first half but starts to fall apart in the final act.

Gareth Tunley's first feature film is an interesting and strong calling card. It struggles to find its feet at times, but it's enough to make you look forward to what he'll do next in a hopefully exciting and fruitful film career.
The Terrible Two struggles to find its footing, pulled apart by horror tropes, dodgy acting and unrealistic characters.
The ideas and plotting of Golding's novel shines through, but this adaptation fails to find its power as it feels the need to rush through to the end.
It's probably not going to win over the Manga faithful, but Death Note is entertaining fun despite its failings.

Prolific director Kinji Fukasaku, best known for Battle Royale, struggles against bloated plots, bringing only a hint of the flair for camerawork and directorial style that he showed in his late career teenagers-slaughtering-each-other masterpiece.
movie_title: New Battles Without Honor and Humanity 1 (Shin jingi naki tatakai) (1974)

movie_review_blurb: It's not a cinematic masterpiece, but if you're in the right mood, Blood Feast is an enjoyable and short watch.
With peerless animation, plenty of laughs and just as much heart, Tokyo Godfathers is an absolute joy. It should appear high on your list of alternative Christmas movies.
Replace starts off shakily but soon settles in to its own groove. You've seen some bits of it before but it's got enough twists and turns to keep you interested until the end.
Shin Godzilla is a film filled with far more government meetings than Godzilla action. A lack of compelling characters and an abundance of bureaucracy make Godzilla's big screen return a let-down.

Despite its love of toilet humour, and attempts to be disgusting and oh-so edgy, Kuso is nothing but a humourless and tiresome trudge, destined to be watched only by young teenagers with poor taste in films.
The weight of dull clichés only makes the stilted dialogue harder to stomach.
By aiming for the audience's sympathy, Lovelace tidies and ultimately silences the star it tries to redeem.
They (Leonard and Foley) do take it to the outer limits that made films like Black Swan and Showgirls enjoyable; meaning it's more enjoyable if you don't take it all so seriously.
This one's for those who know teenagers, have teenagers, are teenagers or have ever been teenagers. You know. Everyone.
It's as if Total Recall met Crank met your PlayStation console - but better, stronger, faster.
Despite the film simply ticking the boxes with the dramatics, its action sequences are some of the most intense and harrowing seen this year.
The Comedian may flounder a bit on stage, but it won't get yanked off by a giant cane.
The picture does take a few exciting bold risks in act one, however, the rest of the movie plays out like a straightforward cable TV movie.
What's there is a well-crafted holiday picture, universal in appeal and scope that lights up laughter and maybe earns a few tears.
Even though a social justice horror film in the pop culture landscape is a clever concept, the one we're given is poorly executed.
Though this isn't a well-crafted movie by any means, when it works, and it does so intermittently, it's legitimately funny.
movie_title: Tyler Perry's Boo! A Madea Halloween (2016)

movie_review_blurb: This is an instant classic that will have you screaming in your seat and cowering behind the seat in front of you.
This animated film is like mainlining a rainbow, snorting Martha Stewart-brand glitter and drinking a glass of ecstasy-spiked champagne. You'll get a high off all the happy.
If you're into art, or simply just have a mild appreciation of it, this is the documentary for you.
movie_title: Sky Ladder: The Art of Cai Guo-Qiang (2016)

movie_review_blurb: This entertaining, enthralling biopic serves up a terrifically digestible cinematic meal.
Never predictable and always genuine, Ade brilliantly captures what it's like to be the frustrated daughter of a loving-but-inappropriate father.
This unsettling phantasmagoric, psychological thriller unnerves with its sharp slaying of the Hollywood industry's rampant sexism.
Unfortunately, its noble efforts are hampered by troubled beginnings, which spiral into a very problematic third act that ultimately self-destructs.
A woman at the helm not only infuses the series with some new blood, but also inherently brings the defiantly feminist voice of the series' protagonist into the foreground.
Unfortunately, the film's ubiquitous phrase, "don't think it, don't say it," is all-too-easily expanded to include "don't see it."
B-movie glory is well-earned with this exXxhilarating, exXxciting, exXxceptionally entertaining feature. It's a v-indecent amount of fun.
This would have been better served as a segment on Drunk History.
This doggo-driven film is a genuinely heartwarming tale about the enriching gifts these relationships bring. It's guaranteed to make your heart swell.
Even though it's not perfect, and borrows heavily from the master of suspense, The Girl On The Train serves as a satisfying, entertaining adaptation.
In order to make it through, you'll have to be committed.
With clunky dialogue and an excessively stupid building mystery, Foley's slavishly faithful adaptation is the best unintentional comedy of the year.
Director Chad Stahelski's highly anticipated sequel more than delivers on its promise to be not just a great action movie, but a great movie. Period.
The Great Wall is one of the seven wonders of the world. Director Zhang Yimou's The Great Wall, however, is not.
Who would've ever thought Peele would peel away from comedy to write and direct such assured work as he's done here. It's socially relevant bent is clever.
Though it's a touch problematic, overall, it's cute and yields some genuine laughs and poignancy.
While it's got a killer cast, and is well-shot, the material is painfully problematic.
Painfully dull, excruciatingly unfunny and mind-numbingly frustrating, there's a multitude of reasons why you'll be left asking, "Why did I even bother?"
Berg takes us on a harrowing ride that's not only a fitting tribute to the intelligence and compassion of those heroes, but also a searing indictment.
Not only did the filmmakers forget who these characters are, their "nothing is sacred" mentality has morphed, curdling into something much more mean-spirited and duplicitous.
Engages your head and heart in equal measure.
It's the best one yet as it diverges (pun intended) from anything the franchise has done before.
Desplechin's haunting and heartbreaking rumination on the growing pains of growing up adds up to a story with strong connective tissue that's well worth seeing.
movie_title: My Golden Days (Trois Souvenirs De Ma Jeunesse) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: It's almost ironic that Vardalos' first film dealt with establishing her identity within her family unit, as this film can't find its identity - or provide a hilarious plot.
Feeling like a rough assembly of the deleted scenes of the film we should be watching, it's mind-numbingly flat and passionless.
Rich, vivid and immersive, this is unlike anything you've ever seen - even surpassing the original.
While it's immensely entertaining and has a biting sense of humor to boot, the film feels more like an Avengers series film than a stand-alone Cap pic.
Even though Louder Than Bombs has a gray, dour side (show me one "grief movie" that doesn't), there's a lot of hopefulness that resonates louder.
Despite the long run time and obvious filler, this is a wholly entertaining blockbuster of superhero magnitude.
Maybe it could have used some more Leeroy Jenkins. As it is, this should be renamed "Snorecraft."
Enthralling and enchanting, the sweetly sentimental story is as much a tale about a special friendship as it is a meta comment on the transportive power of filmmaking.
Officer Downe is brought to us by clown #6 in Slipknot. Maybe films directed by clowns #1-5 are far less misogynist. We'll never know.
Superbly surreal, it marks the impressive debut of a handful of staggering new voices in cinema.
It's funny, beautifully animated and cute - it just forgot to add an emotional punch.
If you're into cute, tender and endearing mother-daughter narratives, this is your new jam.
This should serve to please the midnight masses - so long as that crowd keeps their expectations within the gates.
Amateur and glacially-paced, the angsty drama feels aimless, remedial and rote.
Brave, honest and heartfelt, this is a fairly solid debut from the first-time filmmakers.
While it's equal parts funny, poignant and trenchant, the film mostly acts as a pulpit for Birbiglia to vent his frustrations pointedly at the person who eclipsed his career.
DeMonaco stops short, abruptly only scratching the surface with his observations about politics and religion, choosing to favor painting evil with laughable broadstrokes.
Although the ensemble and energy of The Infiltrator are good, the film as a whole comes up a little short.
This is nightmare fuel.
Nerveplays more as a survival-of-the-fittest lesson - a Darwinism-fueled cautionary tale for the GoPro generation.
It's almost as if the director, along with the editor/ screenwriter, played Bourne Bingo and the winning card became the finished film.
This is the perfect way to update an already existing film - by never drawing from the nostalgia of the original, creating it's own unique song.
It's a challenge to emerge from this immersive tale without being forever affected.
You may wanna have a barf bag nearby because it's an edge-of-your-seat, unrelenting, chilling and intense adventure - and quite possibly the best alien movie of the year.
Its cinematics are sleek, performances are solid, and the narrative is mind-numbingly simple. Yet the filmmakers infuriatingly manage to mess it up at almost every turn.
The logline sounds like a darkly comedic fictional madcap caper. However, this insanely catchy hook is actually an utterly chilling, harrowing affair.
This awe-inducing spectacle not only follows up on some major lingering questions, but also marinates longer on the original's heady concepts and gift for world-building.
Burton's fantastical magical adventure dips into quirk and gothic horror where it can in order to make it unique - only it lacks any sort of identity in its beauty.
movie_title: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Despite all the good is posits, The Boss Baby can never escape looking like a fake movie inside a real one - and altogether feeling like a redundancy.
This is an intelligent, efficient 70's style thriller that weaves an inspired narrative fabric.
While the movie has more in common with the eighties animated television series, it disappointingly turns into more of a conventional journey than where it begins.
It's not a good [mystery] per se, but it's almost what you'd expect from the brothers handling genre material.
The humble artist gets a loving tribute wrapped in a slick promotional package. However, it only scratches the surface whilst getting to the heart of the genius.
movie_title: Manolo, The Boy Who Made Shoes For Lizards (2017)

movie_review_blurb: For as much as it is smart, visceral and riveting, it's also rather befuddling, unsatisfying and vexing.
If you found the first to be offensive, then maybe this [sequel] is for you. But for all others, with most of the wild irreverence gone, this one is more pyrite than gold.
Lacking genuine scares, smarts or suspense, this Friend Request should be denied and blocked.
Rousing, riveting and triumphant, this portrait of a hero is electrifying in terms of the genre and the awards season rush.
It's incredibly true to the show's iconography and narrative themes of female empowerment
Madden gives us a heroine, maybe not to emulate, but to fete with Miss Sloane, the greatest movie Aaron Sorkin never wrote.
Director Pablo Larraín's biopic JACKIE is soaked in atmosphere, bleeding emotion, life, death, happiness, sadness and anxiety.
The character-driven drama is filled with humanity, authenticity and simplicity.
It's a heartwarming, heartrending and heartbreaking portrait - and it'll leave you in tears.
The animated musical-action-adventure will leave you feeling encouraged and empowered. It's joyous and flawless - fitting, as our heroine embodies the same qualities.
[The filmmakers] have put evident passion behind their adaptation of King's previously thought "unfilmable" novel, turning it into a gripping, visceral thriller.
These characters experience universal conflicts all within the cushy, cozy confines of cinema's answer to a Pottery Barn catalog. It's a most welcomed cinematic escape.
Packing it to the gills with character actors may give it a modicum of gravitas, but it doesn't do anything to buoy Landesman's poorly-executed script which sinks like lead.
movie_title: Mark Felt: The Man Who Brought Down the White House (2017)

movie_review_blurb: While it holds two superb performances from its leads and is a beautifully rendered portrait of the human spirit, it's not without its faults.
This destined-to-be cult classic is deliriously psychotic, deliciously wicked and subversive. These gals slay - literally.
Although this high concept slasher pic borrows elements from [other] films, it blessedly does a few original things to make the formula feel fresh and fun.
Though it doesn't come tumbling off the too-high pedestal it built, it does noticeably lose its balance. It's more about managing unreasonable expectations.

movie_review_blurb: This is an utterly adorable, endearing and wonderful all-ages feature that's as much a love letter to the hand-drawn art form as it is to comedy in general.

Locker is merciless in its wretched view of life during wartime. IEDs, suicide bombers, even old-school sniper fire -- all these things are around to remind soldiers that death is imminent at any waking minute.

Toy Story 3 is just the right mix of adventure, joy and, most of all, wonder that we all need right now.
As far as documentaries on the late, reggae-singing revolutionary Bob Marley go (and I've seen a couple in my time), Marley is definitely the most comprehensive -- almost exhaustingly so.
The flick teeters between feel-good message movie and a burlesque of gay panic ...
Man, I'm such a sucker for movies about grumpy old men taking trips.

A cleverly constructed riot that wrings constant laughs from its premise without bleeding it dry, What We Do in the Shadows is also another reminder that maybe we should leave vampire movies to independent filmmakers.
movie_title: What We Do In The Shadows (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Mistress America remains clever and entertaining even as the star-director writing duo exposes the confusion and loneliness lurking beneath the hipster façade.

While Zemeckis, who co-wrote the film with Christopher Browne, makes sure the movie looks wondrous, most of the characters are campy caricatures, especially after Petit and company touch down in the Big Apple and mingle with the Noo Yawk folk.

Thanks to Kikuchi's stubborn, sympathetic performance and Zellner's flair for desolate-yet-captivating composition... the movie rises above its silly premise and puts the audience in a fortress of solitude along with its protagonist.
Patchy but endearing, The Wrecking Crew is both a sonorous scrapbook and a loquacious love letter.
Iris is indeed delightful, mostly because you spend a good hour and 20 minutes with a delightful person.
From the jump, Tomorrowland is devoted more to looking good than being good.
The result is nearly two hours of the kind of alpha-male self-indulgence I thought went out of style with Ed Hardy T-shirts and Four Loko drinks.
Dope... won my vote for best film of the summer... And unless anything else blows me the hell away between now and December, it'll be my favorite movie of the year.
Listen turns out to be quite haunting.
Thankfully, watching [Tom Cruise] do all of this is still great fun.
Heaven Knows What is the latest critical love train I just can't hop aboard.

Director Asif Kapadia... rounds up revelatory, even joyous footage and interviews. The film he's assembled from them is a heartbreaking portrait of a major talent with her fair share of demons, which only haunted her more once she became a star.

Sandra spends the titular amount of time going all over the city, approaching her coworkers and trying to get them on her side. If that doesn't sound very interesting, then you don't know about the Dardennes' knack for keeping it fascinatingly real.

Through a vivid collection of clips and interviews, this enlightening, rousing documentary shows us how these proud but cautious athletes have a complex love-hate relationship with the place they call home.
A wondrous, whacked-out look at people doing what they think is right.
Possibly the season's -- even the year's -- most stunning, complex film.
A knock-around sex comedy where the actual act is hardly the point, The Overnight shows that wedded bliss can also be a rough, raunchy trip.

Hopefully, The Wolfpack will also remind some parents that you can't hold onto your kids forever. Their desire to see and do everything is too strong. Sometimes, you just gotta let those little bastards roam.
Tangerine will go on to be a gonzo, offbeat Christmas story for Grinchy people who are sick of watching the usual sentimental yuletide sap during the holidays.

Like so many prior films about immigrants looking for a better life on these shores, Brooklyn lays out a wondrous, overwhelming and romantic vision of America's past -- the same vision that brought people here in the first place.
The biggest sin The Hunter's Prayer commits is being too dumb to enjoy.
Costa-Gavras certainly found an intriguing leading man in Elmaleh, with his ice-cold stare that may remind audiences of Steve McQueen at his most penetrating.
Kastner has crafted an entertainingly kitschy version of an Errol Morris film ...

While not a lot of Hell Baby works... the movie does seem destined to be the sort of acquired-taste howler that will most likely attract people who recognize how ridiculous horror movies can be-and, of course, stoners.
As much as it wants to show how keeping it in your pants can be downright debilitating for some, Thanks for Sharing ultimately proves to be an unsatisfying, relentlessly depriving experience.
Escape from Tomorrow often makes good on its aspiration to stick it to the man in the mouse suit, but let's not get carried away: Miley Cyrus is currently doing just that to much greater effect.
An occasionally doleful but otherwise lively trip, Muscle Shoals is yet another cinematic shout-out to those unsung heroes who came out of nowhere and made music that mattered.
This retro-futuristic romance (set in a world where people dress like colorful Quakers) has not only a lyrical sharpness but also the most sincere of faces.

I will say that of all the Oscar-bait movies the Weinstein Company has released this holiday season, Mandela: Long Walk to Freedom is one that won't make you grimace in agony while you're watching it.
A ribald, ridiculous party in the sky, I'm So Excited is basically Almodóvar's Soul Plane-and I mean that as a compliment.
It's a sad state of affairs when movies like Fruitvale Station have to show everyone what they should know by now: Black people are people, too.
Joyous, uplifting, melancholy and nostalgic, Twenty Feet From Stardom is a stunning salute to the singers who stay in the background, but whose talents can never be contained there.
This is the most functional tale of dysfunctional-family drama I've ever heard.
Gimme the Loot may scare off future visitors to New York City, but it'll certainly make those who grew up there homesick as hell.

Even though God is actually mentioned in the closing, special-thanks credits, dude couldn't unfortunately work His/Her magic and prevent this film from being the uneven, preposterously out-of-control wreck that it is. Can the church say "Amen"?

With Ginger & Rosa, Potter once again documents the usually lonely road a woman takes in finding out who she really is, this time showing it from the perspective of someone who isn't even a woman yet.
Identity Thief is supposed be a fun time, but robs you of it the whole 111 minutes you're sitting there watching it.

The movie, like the play it's based on, is more about reminding audiences that talented people are often still talented in their later years. It's safe to say that Quartet will be the feel-good movie of the year-for anyone over 65.
He was the perfect by-product of the Reagan era and, as Evocateur reminds us, someone rabid, right-wing broadcasters should gratefully praise every day of their lives.
movie_title: Évocateur: The Morton Downey Jr. Movie (2013)

movie_review_blurb: As the title oh-so-obviously implies, it's a love that will-well, you know.
As much as [De Palma] beautifies this mess-the movie's so sleek, you'll worry that the cast is gonna slip off the damn screen-it's still a mess.
Violence may be served up in copious amounts, but McDonagh also creates characters who have no qualms going gently into that good night.
On a list of Allen's worst films, this, my friends, would rank very low.
Ultimately, Elaine Stritch: Shoot Me makes you root for her even when you've had your fill of her.
Unfortunately, this movie has so many damn things percolating all through it that it ultimately seems unfocused and painfully earnest.
Although Red Sparrow succeeds at being the sort of routinely paranoid, melodramatic secret-agent yarn that used to drop back in the Reagan era, it overdoes it in the brutality department.
The filmmakers do an effective job at making a clever horror show out of postpartum depression. So it's a shame the movie goes off the deep end in the final act ...
Unfortunately, all of these factors fail to coalesce in the end, as the jumbled, manic finale builds to a messy implosion.
Film Stars Don't Die in Liverpool is a generic, sentimental attempt to pay tribute to one of the more intriguing femmes fatales to ever grace the silver screen.
movie_title: Film Stars Don't Die in Liverpool (2017)

movie_review_blurb: From the storyline to the score to the climactic reaction shots to the purposely head-scratching ending, Lies We Tell is crammed, histrionic, and way too damn much.
Bilal achieves a vibrantly noble tone even when it stumbles plot-wise.
movie_title: Bilal: A New Breed of Hero (2018)

movie_review_blurb: A hysterically entertaining train wreck.
Think The Happening, but only parents get affected - and the movie's actually good this time around.
[Ridley] Scott doesn't seem to know whether to play this so-insane-it-has-to-be-true story for dark laughs or to dramatize it as another gripping, suspenseful fact-based tale.
movie_title: All the Money in the World (2017)

movie_review_blurb: You may not take a single frame of this movie seriously, especially whenever Pacino is shuffling around, waving a gun and talking like he's desperately in need of a mint julep.
The stench of needlessly convoluted derivativeness lingers throughout this flick.
Despite its title, Revolt isn't a movie that will incite either revolution or revulsion in viewers. In fact, you might walk away from it with a serious case of whatever.
I'm thankful No Greater Love is around to make people realize how much war heroes need our love, help, and support once they come back home.
Here comes Mayhem, with a wild mix of white-collar beatdowns and bloodshed that will indeed satisfy all the hard-working nine-to-fivers.
Funny and sad, poignant and profound, elegant and elegiac, ambitious and ambiguous, The Great Beauty is one of the most utterly enjoyable movies I've seen in years.
If The Wind Rises is indeed Miyazaki's last hurrah, he goes out on a graceful, all-encompassing note.
The movie certainly found the right screenwriter in Tom McCarthy.
It's quite amazing that both Delpy and Rock pull this off, convincingly playing a couple who, despite being polar opposites, are straight-up smitten with each other.
The unconvincing, histrionic script makes all of this seem more contrived than controlled.
The movie is hardly top-notch stuff.
The movie almost makes me consider watching an episode of Glee-almost.
With The Adventures of Tintin, Steven Spielberg remembers that even if you make a movie that isn't about that much, at least make it an exciting, awe-inspiring movie about not that much.
Unlike the Bond films, this movie reminds us that being a British government agent is always a job, and rarely an adventure.
Unfortunately, with all the deep pluses Shame serves up, its clumsy minuses are too glaring and unpardonable.
They basically patch a narrative together by jacking the best moments from fun popcorn flicks like The Negotiator and Inside Man.
Tim and Eric are more tolerable in small doses. When they try to stretch their shenanigans to a feature-length format, the results are even more nonsensical-and even more antagonistic.
movie_title: Tim and Eric's Billion Dollar Movie (2012)

movie_review_blurb: The movie is still one tacky sight.

The producers had the right idea hiring former Buffy the Vampire Slayer scribe Marti Noxon to write the screenplay. Unfortunately, they also hired director Craig Gillespie, who once again shows why he shouldn't be allowed around film equipment.
It may look like a holiday trifle, but it's still a sleigh ride worth taking.
If you still enjoy the sort of bathroom humor that had you in hysterics back in grade school, this movie delivers those juvenile gags (in every sense of the word) in droves.
They are the people of Ferguson - people like you and me. And as the painful but powerful film Whose Streets? documents, they would really prefer it if the cops treated them as such.
Unfortunately, as much as you might want to be impressed by its kamikaze visual ingenuity, Bushwick is a hollow, ultimately unsatisfying exercise in organized chaos.
An uplifting portrait of a debilitated man driven to excel by a relentless desire to live life and love those who surround him.
You can tell Besson went all out in making a faithful adaptation. But it's his overeagerness to give us a comprehensive Valerian epic that makes the whole thing a bloated slog.
movie_title: Valerian and the City of a Thousand Planets (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The script is needlessly convoluted and filled with horrible ideas and you-knew-that-was-coming twists.
Blues is mostly a spirited, rambling trip through the history of this American music, but that journey is under the cloud of a melancholy bleakness.
Once Upon a Time in Venice is a sterling example of how a lazy star can make a bad movie even worse.
movie_title: Once Upon a Time in Venice (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Both Sharif and Ahmed make sure audiences leave Nowhere to Hide well aware that Iraq remains a war zone - one where innocent people remain caught in the crossfire.
... I Do is about as saccharine and screwball as any ensemble Hollywood rom-com.

If anything, The Muppets succeeds in reminding us why audiences both young and old adored these talking pieces of felt in the first place: They were the first icons of family entertainment to keep it real.
We Bought a Zoo certainly wins this year's prize for most mediocre, heartwarming family film to win over audiences this holiday season.

Much like its protagonist, the film appears to enjoy taking the piss out of its audience, giving them a cynical yet cheeky neo-noir that tweaks the usual conventions and comes up with a story that may be familiar, but is told in fresh fashion.
Killer Joe is such a hideously over-the-top, black-hearted view of Southern-fried scumbags that even Texans like myself can't get offended.
Band is a likable enough film.
While Goldthwait's heart is in the right place, it's unlikely the blood spilled in his film will make annoying, loathsome people finally straighten ... up.

The kind of forced, deceptive, quasi-quirky heart-warmer that brings older people (and rabid dog lovers) to the art house, Darling Companion ultimately isn't about finding the dog. It's about these shrill, boring-ass people finding each other.
It's really the most sympathetic salute to mothers Disney has released since Freaky Friday.

I won't reveal if these two adult learners rekindle the flame they thought was out long ago. But I will tell you this: I never thought seeing Meryl Streep pull an Alanis Morissette would be one of the highlights of my summer.
It doesn't rely on annoying pop references or scenes of shameless schmaltz. Credit is probably due to executive producer Guillermo del Toro.
Margin Call effectively portrays these masters of the universe as flawed folk who were just as ill-informed, unaware and ultimately scared of losing it all as the general public.
Be prepared to find yourself trying to find sympathy and compassion for the Siegels.
You can guess where the movie goes.
Mama Africa shows how Miriam Makeba was the antithesis of a diva. Right up until her death in 2008, she was a woman who cared too damn much.
The incoherent, mostly-out-of-control Dark Signal is too damn much.
Rememory proves that Peter Dinklage is ready for his close-up. When is Hollywood gonna be ready?
Even though this dusty bit of true crime is limp and flimsy as hell, Last Rampage does give a few seasoned actors the opportunity to chew all the scenery they can in a 93-minute movie.
In the end, this relentlessly scenic travelogue/valentine is Willer literally giving her old man peace of mind.
Crazy tropes turn what could've been a cleverly made, low-key ghost story into a ludicrous, laughable mess.
While it may win over folks with its woozy, dreamlike, visual look ... Bellflower may also disgust others with its nasty, nihilistic narrative.
For his characters' demises, co-writer/director Eli Craig (aka Sally Field's son) comes up with the sort of ridiculous Rube Goldberg setups you would usually find in Final Destination movies.
There's a specificity to screenwriter Eric Monte's memories of growing up on the Near North Side in the early 1960s that transcends mere imitation.
White Comanche is a would-be cult item, albeit one with a weak pulse, since the Shatner character who gets the most screen time, isn't endowed with much personality.
It's a well-honed farce that gave Edwards and his cast a solid framework in which to improvise, which they did to superlative effect.
movie_title: What Did You Do in the War, Daddy? (1966)

movie_review_blurb: What hurts The Beat Generation more than anything else is Charles Haas' failure to maintain a consistent directorial tone.
Broken Horses lays on the heavy-handed symbolism so thick that every action is freighted with significance that the flimsy cardboard cutouts populating it can't support.
It could have come across as strictly a work-for-hire gig, but it displays enough Hitchcockery to show he wasn't as disengaged from the material as he would later claim he was.
The breakneck pace becomes wearying, though, as the action rarely pauses long enough for the characters or the audience to catch their breath.
movie_title: Les tribulations d'un Chinois en Chine (Up to His Ears) (2013)

movie_review_blurb: It's an overblown remake of William Wyler's 1955 film The Desperate Hours.
It's a picturesque adventure filled with a logic-bending plot and death-defying stunts.
The Pope Of Greenwich Village benefits immensely from Rosenberg's decision to film on location in Little Italy, which gives every scene a lived-in feel.
Dog Soldiers remains Marshall's most potent distillation of taut action, unrelenting horror, and gallows humor.

Holdridge and Saasen should get credit for making sure the obstacles to their happiness aren't romance-movie contrivances, but rather the sorts of things that happen to people while they're busy making other plans.
The film is at its best when tackling the often uncomfortable discussion of what Israelis have learned, borrowed, and absorbed from the Arab cuisines that existed there before creation of the state.
Fans of this kind of deadpan humor are guaranteed to get a few chuckles out of this one. All of the actors are marvelously horrible, and in this movie, bad equals good.
The interviews with the band members and the behind-the-scenes footage ... make for an entertaining and illuminating experience.
An ambitious, well-acted film!
One of the funniest movies to come along in awhile.

This is not a movie for the squeamish, by any means. But for those who like their thrillers dark and their heroes a bit more complicated and flawed than the average shoot-without-a-blink type so prevalent in today's movies, 8MM fills the bill.
Easily one of the best documentaries on any subject ever made. It is also one of the most cinematically influential.

It is full of enough great sight gags and dead-on casting that anyone who has ever suffered in a cubicle surrounded by brain-dead twits and bonehead bosses will be able to pick out almost everyone from his office among the characters.
Some of it is funny, most of it is predictable and Smith's character is so annoying that it's just not realistic that Davidson would put up with all this hassle just for a possible roll in the hay.

The movie should appeal to the 8- to 13-year-old girls who have made the group rich, but it has enough for the parents who may go to the movie dreading 93 minutes of over-Spice and find themselves coming away entertained.
She may not be a saint, and may even be as manipulative as she is portrayed, but even Love deserves a little more objectivity than Broomfield brings to this film.
There's never a moment when you think it's a real chimp, so even that novelty is nonexistent.
If you must rent it, at least wait for a half-price night.
Even with a great cast and a great story idea, the movie fails to build even a hint of suspense.
The Martian, true to itself, simply gets the job done.
The movie shows how you can rationalise the ends justifying the means, but you don't know where the ends will take you.

Jackman's theatrical charm helps tie together the many influences, but it's hard to be inspired by that familiar trope of the fated boy prophesied to change everything. The movie takes seriously concepts thoroughly satirised by The Lego Movie.
Shooting on location and in the Italian Alps, Kormakur emphasises the constant sloping height and tenuous links to safety.
Pixels' predecessors, such as Ghostbusters, had an irreverent disrespect for authority and a deadpan outlook, but few of the many elements here are developed beyond the rudimentary.
The mood is restless, the tone is energetic, and influences are embraced and discarded quicker than you can say: "We Are the Best adolescent Pulp Fiction on the Go this year".
Pattinson, who has pushed himself into more demanding roles after his own teen idol phase in the Twilight franchise, is the best thing in this flawed, sometimes emotionally shapeless movie.
Aside from Vikander the period playfulness falls short.

The final scenes are rushed, but the film never completely loses that sense of adolescent awe. The characters do become fantastic, but there's still something ordinary -- and very recognisable -- about them.
The character, and the actor, need some variety, with Thor: The Dark World doing just enough to keep Marvel's increasingly unwieldy construction in motion before The Avengers' 2015 reunion.

Black Mass too often plays like a tribute to previous crime films, particularly Martin Scorsese's Goodfellas, but while it cops the stylistic licks and the attitude, there's little of the telling detail or astute psychology.
Kick-Ass 2 has a twisted energy, and from the first scene, in which a caustic Mindy teaches Dave about the importance of a bulletproof vest, it tries everything it can think of.
The worse things get for these two women, the closer they ultimately are, giving Miss You Already an authenticity beneath the attitude.
Generally amusing but deeply predictable ... It lacks the loopy excess of Ferrell and Wahlberg's previous collaboration, 2010's cop comedy The Other Guys.

It's a busy but not entirely satisfying film, thankfully elevated by Hardy's performance, which goes past the usual technical trickery to create the palpable feeling of a shared identity trying to separate.
This impeccably crafted Gothic horror tale... doesn't quite come to fruition despite some vivid elements.
Few directors are building a better body of work than Noah Baumbach, the New Yorker whose deft contemporary comedies are growing in snappy wit, barbed compassion and social critique.

Man Up is composed of scenes that tell us we're watching a romantic comedy: inopportune conversations, annoyed exchanges... embarrassing encounters, and speeches of romantic dedication made before a hushed crowd.
A farcical comedy that is too often forced instead of funny.
Suffragette makes a case for the historic importance of these renegade women, who launched the first wave of feminism, but you may wish the stirring narrative wasn't so streamlined.
What's absent is something fresh that illuminates Scott's technique anew.
This dual take on Wilson's life doesn't just celebrate its subject, it understands him. As in one of his recording sessions, all the notes fit together.
It has a subtle but unsparing aesthetic; the most powerful camera shot is to slowly pull back from a busy desk, silently indicating the story's terrible breadth.
Steve Jobs, a study of the late co-founder of Apple that takes place in the hours and minutes prior to three separate product launches, is a powerful film with little subtlety.
[Brooklyn] doesn't just look back wistfully at the past, it also transcends the period setting with powerfully timeless questions: Where do I belong? What can I make of my life?
You never do find out what we talk about when we talk about love, but this wonderfully inexplicable movie is well worth adoring.
If the monstrously terrible scale of the Holocaust makes it impossible to truly understand...now the Hungarian feature Son of Saul offers a gripping new perspective.
Hail, Caesar! has its moments of pleasures, but often it leaves you with what Laurence Laurentz asks Hobie to deliver on camera: 'a mirthless chuckle'.
If Moorhouse's film sometimes falls out of step, then it at least has the self-belief to go out in a blaze of glory.
The most pleasurably complete Pixar film since 2004's The Incredibles, Inside Out delivers a witty and empathetic answer to the eternal lament of, "What is going on inside your head?"

This is Wan's first major Hollywood production after more than a decade of profitable horror outings including Saw and Insidious, and it's disappointing that neither the gonzo gore of the former nor the calculating restraint of the latter register here.
What endures, however, is the pleasure of a Hollywood movie with a female focus: they not only dominate the cast, but also set the prevailing tone.
In Philippe Garrel's finely wrought In the Shadow of Women ... the struggles of the creative class are repeatedly contrasted with the weight of 20th-century French history.
Folman makes one phantasmagorical leap after another, adding a live-action coda, but the visual freedom doesn't expand the story, it abandons it.
Most of the accidents that befall the Cooper clan are annoying or embarrassing and even a car accident is more about cosmetic damage to the vehicle than a passenger actually being harmed.
movie_title: Alexander and the Terrible, Horrible, No Good, Very Bad Day (2014)

movie_review_blurb: The film itself is rich with spirit and possessed of a dry humour, if not overly concerned about representing the world as Turner saw it. Spall makes a man who tried to give little away hugely expressive.
Singer's direction is capable, with generally fulfilling use of 3-D technology and a thankfully dry sense of humour.
The Lego Movie is an intricate piece that delights in both celebrating and mocking movie archetypes, the commercialisation of childhood experience, and the authoritarian hands of parents.
Hoop Dreams director Steve James mainly avoids eulogising [Ebert], instead painting a picture of man who loved the movies, but could be prickly and given to excess.
With a soundtrack of grinding frequencies and uneasy point-of-view camera shots, the everyday becomes otherworldly.
In terms of plot and performance, John Wick is cleanly predictable, but the execution is impressive.
It's heavier than a comedy about a gibberish-spewing guy in a giant head ought to be, but that's what makes it a thing of heartbreaking, oddball beauty.

It's still hard to believe that the sturdy pleasures and arresting craft of Peter Jackson's first Middle-earth trilogy with The Lord of the Rings has been so thoroughly undone by the repetitive excess and clumsy additions of The Hobbit, his second one.
movie_title: The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Penguins of Madagascar is so verbally dexterous - and the animation by contrast little more than bright and familiar - that this could well be an adult spoof hiding out in a flick supposedly made for primary school students.
The Imitation Game walks a fine line in making the familiar effective, also reflecting A Beautiful Mind at points.
It is so fluent and so certain -- both in its humanism and its depiction of institutionalised savagery.
[An] exceedingly good period thriller.
The film is frank but rarely simplistic and Vallee, who is becoming an important filmmaker, trusts the audience to do as Cheryl did and find the right path to follow.
The Interview at its best is just intermittently amusing, with an obsession about the sanctity of bottoms. These boys need to stop clenching.
[An] ambitious and often arresting French drama.
A deeply impressive thriller where the deeds are frightening yet the momentum is bracing.
Chops together familiar ideas and design from many far better features.
Crazy enough to entertain while illuminating the sad reality of never quite getting what you want.

Kenneth Branagh's lavish live-action telling of the folktale made familiar to many by Disney's 1950 animated feature film is a faithful take that derives pleasure in updating expectations and absolutely never dashing them.
It's brilliant.
Black Sea is another strongly made drama from British filmmaker Kevin Macdonald and, like The Last King of Scotland and State of Play, is about a protagonist in an untenable situation.
Josh wants Jamie's life, Jamie wants Josh's status. Each generation suspects the next, but in their division Baumbach has made his most pleasing and accessible film yet.
Everything [Whedon] did so well on the first meeting of these Marvel comic book creations he achieves once again, which makes for a movie both enjoyable and somewhat repetitive.
You can read this droll film as a fable, and that's probably better than as a picture of mental illness.

Unfriended starts to creak by the end, even as the tension is ratcheted up to a hysterical peak, but it's neither bloody nor charged by adrenalin. With the participants sitting at desks or on beds it has a curious inertia.
With telling performances, Ex Machina spans sci-fi philosophy and a romantic triangle, but ultimately it's a horror movie where the monsters are men.
A revved-up vision of gloriously twisted design, propulsive momentum and resonant mythmaking.
Ride Along 2 tries hard but has little that is new or unexpected to offer.

Spielberg has already made one brilliant movie about a young English child thrust into a dangerous environment with 1987's Empire of the Sun, and perhaps a further touch of darkness would have added some contrast here.

What the film needed was a young Peter Jackson... but it's left with a surprisingly straight tone and the sense that this is an amusing idea for a comedy sketch stretched out to feature length. The only threat to your brain is boredom.
Saulnier's quiet dynamic ratchets up the tension before bursts of horror-like mayhem make clear that they are fighting merely to stay alive, not to make a point.
All of Hillcoat's films are about worlds that have nightmarishly run of control ... It dives so deep into the pathology of corruption that no-one is untainted, and the grace notes are pure gore.

The sheer amount of digital effects, often poorly executed to the point of distraction, diminishes the feel for atmosphere and the clever reworking of genre that usually marks the features of Australian filmmaker Alex Proyas.
The film is rarely staid and it is ego, whether endowed by the instruments or not, that often shines through in the overly busy structure that leaps from one tangent to the next.

The humour here is derived from the gap between a fantastic scenario and the everyday outcomes. It's [Waititi's] ability to create a self-contained world - complete with amateurish songs - which makes the resulting dialogue so amusing.
A work that not only references the historical setting and panoramic desert compositions of David Lean's Lawrence of Arabia, but the refined desire and period elegance of the Merchant Ivory canon.

A busy but perfunctory experience, complete with some blatant product placement for a Macau casino. The idea that these movies speak for the individual against an encroaching system is one illusion you can easily see through.
A plan gone awry is a traditional screen farce, but God Willing never builds up the comic energy to sustain such an approach; the schemes peter out before they can attain a lunatic silliness.
[A] harrowing exploration of atonement that establishes a stark atmosphere from the opening scene.
[It] zips along on childish impulses, a cartoonish view of good and evil, and a genial approach to saving the world that thankfully opts for goofy as opposed to gravitas.
movie_title: Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles: Out of the Shadows (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Cannily written and directed by Michael Showalter (Wet Hot American Summer), so that an air of whimsical hope and discovery never quite comes unstuck at the hands of embarrassment and recrimination.
The script from writer/director Michael Petroni is so ruthlessly focused on planting symbols and advancing menacing clues that the protagonist's journey into his own past begins to feel pre-ordained.
The thinness of the plot -- as opposed to the sturdy themes -- and sitcom-y snap of the dialogue only tire towards the end.
A quietly audacious coming-of-age tale lodged inside a psychological horror film.
Cheadle is compelling, but his movie sometimes struggle to make the many elements harmonious.

Dory can fritter away your interest, and the prominence also exposes the limitations of DeGeneres as a voice actor: daffy blather is a cinch for the talk-show host, but she absolutely milks any attempt at pathos.
If you're already Bored with the Rings, then fantasy epic Warcraft is the last thing you'll want to see.
The film crackles with fetid electricity amid a strange nocturnal beauty.
Doleful humour, abrasive familiarity, and an avoidance of horror tropes such as shock cuts, anchors the film's mood in the everyday, even as the atmosphere relentlessly darkens.

It's understandable that disabled activists have protested, given that this clumsy English romantic melodrama suggests the loss in quality of life for a quadriplegic is such that euthanasia is the only course of action.
Expertly staged inside a Hong Kong hospital, the latest film from prolific Hong Kong director Johnnie To is a matter of life and death from three outlooks.
Even as Asia is dropped on Europe the film lacks the comic book enthusiasm and clear-eyed momentum of the 1996 original.
The film is riddled with cryptic mysteries, not to mention Cheech and Chong, and it plays as an urbane older brother to David Lynch's psychosexual masterpiece Blue Velvet.
